title: EU and US consider sanctions against Ukraine as death toll reaches 26

body:
5.10pm GMT

Markets close mixed

After the recent volatility it was a slightly calmer day in the markets, fat finger trades aside. In the wake of the Federal Reserve trimming its monthly bond buying programme by another $10bn, investors continued to fret about the effect on emerging markets. But positive US GDP figures - although pointing to further tapering by the Fed - were received well by US markets, while in Europe there were some signs of positivity. Overall the closing scores were:

• The FTSE 100 finished down 5.83 points or 0.09% at 6538.45

• Germany's Dax closed up 0.39% at 9373.48

• France's Cac climbed 0.55% to 4180.02

• Italy's FTSE MIB ended 0.38% higher at 19,411

• Spain's Ibex added 0.69% to 9964.5

• Turkey's Bist rose 1.18% to 76,031.78

• Argentina's Buse Merval added 1.06% to 5718.87

In the US, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 141 points or 0.88% higher.

And on that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we'll be back tomorrow.

4.12pm GMT

Greek recovery is fragile, says thinktank

Over to Greece where the country's leading economic think tank, IOBE, has not ruled out national output contracting for a seventh straight year in 2014. Helena Smith in Athens writes:

Releasing its quarterly review earlier today, IOBE was unequivocal: in 2014 the recession-hit Greek economy would finally bottom out, it said, but in sharp contrast to official forecasts it could not be excluded that national output would also contract.

The Athens-based think tank, which was headed by Yannis Stournaras before he took up the post of finance minister in June 2012, said much would depend on the implementation of structural reforms, foreign direct investment and the persistent problem of Greece’s debt overhang – a barrier to international business interest in the country.

IOBE’s research director, Angelos Tsakanikas, who helped draft the report, told me that while the economy was “moving towards zero” it was possible it could still contract.

“There is a slowing down of the depression, we are moving towards stability, towards zero, but this [recovery] is fragile,” he said. “If nothing is done with implementing structural reforms, attracting investment and tackling unemployment, the economy could contract … we could, for example, see it hit minus two.” The macro-economic environment would also play a role. “Last year we had recession in the euro zone. If international trade improves it will be easier for Greeks to export.”

Athens’ pro-bailout coalition government has repeatedly said the economy --- which has shrunk by around 25% since the debt crisis began - will begin to recover in 2014, growing by a predicted 0.6%.

Addressing his parliamentary group today, prime minister Antonis Samaras insisted that Greece was about to pull out of recession – at six years its longest in post-war history. “The country has suffered, and is still suffering, but the worst has been avoided and we are now starting to come out of the crisis. Some seem to forget that we stopped the country from collapsing,” the conservative leader told his MPs. “With the help of God and people’s support we will achieve even more.”

After pulling off the biggest fiscal consolidation ever recorded in an OECD country, optimism is such that Stournaras has declared Greece will also re-enter markets in the summer of 2014. But as IOBE, the economic institute, emphasized in its report, there are worries that not enough has been done to implement structural reforms that would improve business by overhauling an archaic public administration and bureaucracy. Raising the same concerns the Greek parliament’s independent budget office announced on Wednesday that priority to fiscal reforms (at the behest of creditors) had ultimately “weakened the [country’s] long-term prospects for recovery.”

Updated at 4.16pm GMT

3.16pm GMT

Back in the US, and signs of a slowdown in the housing market.

Pending home sales fell 8.7% in December, according to an index from the National Association of Realtors. This was the lowest level since October 2011, although part of the fall was due to the cold weather across the country.

Housing sales have been hit by a rise in mortgage rates, but the cold was pinpointed by NAR economist Lawrence Yun:

Unusually disruptive weather across large stretches of the country in December forced people indoors and prevented some buyers from looking at homes or making offers.

Teunis Brosens at ING Bank said:

This is a nasty surprise, that is probably partly explained by adverse weather conditions in December. It is unclear however to what extent bad weather explains sales weakness. A few bits of good news are that mortgage rates have stabilised since December, and the number of mortgage applications has also recovered to pre-December figures.

There is therefore some ground to believe that today’s plunge in pending sales is a one-off that will party be reversed in the coming months. Still, it is very clear that the housing bonanza of late 2012 and early 2013 is over. The Fed’s tapering is not without consequences, and the housing market is shifting in a lower gear.

Meanwhile Wall Street has opened higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average currently up around 50 points or 0.34%.

Updated at 3.19pm GMT

3.04pm GMT

European Commission President Jose Manuel Barroso is speaking about the state of the economy (at the plenary session of the Committee of the Regions in Brussels):

Updated at 3.06pm GMT

2.20pm GMT

Dow Futures now sharply higher in the wake of the US GDP figures, up 92 points. We'll know shortly how accurate that proves...

1.59pm GMT

The US GDP figures probably mean the Fed could trim another $10bn off its monthly bond buying programme at its March meeting, said ING's Rob Carnell. He said:


US GDP came in right on expectations at 3.2% for the fourth quarter, though this is a pretty good result, and comes after a strong 4.1% figure for the previous three months. The Bureau of Economic analysis estimates that the government shutdown reduced GDP by about 0.3 percentage points. So without this, GDP may have come in closer to 3.5%.

Overall, this is a strong set of data, especially when you take into account the government shutdown, though the GDP price deflators were on the weak side – which may worry some. This should not be enough to detract the Fed from what looks like it will be another $10bn taper at their March FOMC meeting taking monthly QE down to $55bn.

1.43pm GMT

US jobless claims rise

But if GDP figures were in line with expectations, weekly jobless claims rose by more than forecast.

The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefit rose by 19,000 to 348,000 last week compared to an expected figure of 330,000. But analysts pointed out the week included Martin Luther King day, and claims tended to be volatile around Federal holidays. On top of that, claims for Louisiana were estimated because of poor weather.

The Dow Jones Futures, showing a 42 point increase ahead of the GDP and jobless claims data, has slipped to a 35 point predicted rise.

1.37pm GMT

US GDP in line

The US economy grew by 3.2% in the fourth quarter, official figures show, which is bang in line with expectations.

It compares to a 4.1% rise in GDP in the third quarter, and benefited from strong household spending and rising exports. The figures come a day after the US Federal Reserved trimmed its monthly bond buying programme by another $10bn and said that "growth in economic activity picked up in recent quarters."

Consumer spending rose by 3.3%, the strongest since the fourth quarter of 2010 while exports grew by 11.4%.

1.28pm GMT

Emerging market update: "The perfect storm"

Emerging market currencies have clawed back some of this morning's early losses, but the Turkish lira is still down around 0.2% against the US dollar at 2.26.

The Hungarian forint is also down on the day, off 0.6% at 311 to the US dollar.

And the ruble was also hit, touching a record low against the euro and the lowest level since March 2009 against the dollar.

Just chatted with Jeremy Cook of World First, who explained that a range of factors are pushing down emerging market currencies.

For example, the Fed's continued taper, the weak Chinese manufacturing figures (see opening post), political unrest in Ukraine and Thailand, current account deficits in many countries.

This has combined into a perfect emerging market storm.

The Hungarian forint is likely to come under more pressure, Cook added, because its central bank had indicated it wanted to maintain loose monetary policy.

And the Turkey lira is still being hit because traders fear that the huge interest rate hikes on Tuesday night leave them with few other weapons now. Cook added:

﻿There's a school of thought that they've fired their last bullet and not landed a fatal blow in the battle to protect their currency.

And with that, I"m handing over to Nick Fletcher for the rest of the day - starting with the US GDP data for the last quarter, any moment.... Cheers all. GW

Updated at 1.33pm GMT

1.17pm GMT

1.16pm GMT

Data firm Markit reports that the cost of insuring Russian and Ukranian debt against default has risen this morning, suggesting increased worries about both countries.

30-Jan-2014 13:12 - UKRAINE'S 5-YEAR CREDIT DEFAULT SWAPS RISE 62 BPS FROM WED CLOSE TO 999 BPS, HIGHEST SINCE DEC 17 - MARKIT

(That means it would cost almost £1m per year to insure £10m of Ukranian bonds.)

30-Jan-2014 13:12 - RUSSIA 5-YEAR CDS RISE 16 BPS TO 209 BPS, A 6-MONTH HIGH - MARKIT

1.09pm GMT

Although Greece is calmer than during the height of the crisis, protests against the government's austerity programme have not gone away.

A group of health service workers and patient have held a demonstration outside a cancer hospital in Athens this morning, against planned cuts to public health spending:

The protests took place as prime minister Antonis Samaras rejected claims that he might call an early general election, having seen his majority shrivel in recent months.

He also told MPs that Greece would hit its target of a primary surplus (excluding the cost of paying back its debts), saying:

﻿"Based on the most recent data, the primary surplus reached, and I would say exceeds, 1 billion euros,"

Updated at 1.09pm GMT

12.33pm GMT

The New Zealand dollar is another casualty of the volatility in the FX market, down around 0.5% today at 0.816 to the US dollar.

It's struggling after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand central bank voted to leave interest rates unchanged last night, although there's a theory that it could hike next month.

Jane Foley of Rabobank explains:

The worse performing G10 currency over the past 5 days is the New Zealand dollar (NZD).

Last night’s decision by the RBNZ to leave rates on hold weighed on the NZD, though the hawkish commentary by the central bank leaves suggests it will still be the first developed world central bank to hike rates.

The RBNZ described the NZ economic expansion as having “considerable momentum” and stated that it “remains committed to increasing the OCR as needed to keep future average inflation near the 2 percent target mid-point”.

Updated at 12.35pm GMT

11.49am GMT

11.43am GMT

11.41am GMT

HSBC shares soar, suspended, then drop back

Brief drama in the stock market there -- shares in banking giant HSBC soared 10%, forcing the stock to be suspended.

But a few minutes later, it's back where it started - leaving traders wondering if someone accidentally botched an order -- known as a 'fat finger trade' in the City.

Fat-finger blunders are embarrassing, and can be pretty expensive for the offender -- unless the stock market regulator decides to cancel the trades.

Updated at 11.45am GMT

11.27am GMT

Turkey - no capital controls planned

Turkey's finance minister, Mehmet Simsek, has reiterated that the country will not introduce capital controls to try to support the lira.

Simsek told reporters that Turkey would seek to improve the investment environment and continue its reforms, rather than restricting the flow of capital.

Reuters has more details:

﻿Speaking to reporters a day after Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan referred to a possible "out of the ordinary" economic package, Simsek said it was too early to start discussing tax breaks for certain sectors.

Updated at 11.27am GMT

10.57am GMT

Further proof that the eurozone is no longer the big threat to the global economy -- Italy's borrowing costs just hit a euro-era low at a €8.45bn auction of debt this morning.

The Italian Treasury sold five year bonds at an average yield of just 2.43%, the lowest interest rate since the euro was created.

It also sold 10-year bonds at an average yields of 3.81%, down from 4.1% last month.

10.40am GMT

Business and consumer confidence across the eurozone has hit its highest level since July 2011, driven by a pickup in Germany (unsurprising) and France (more surprising).

That's according to the EC's monthly survey which showed that economic confidence has risen for the ninth month in a row as the perils of the eurozone debt crisis receded.

Sentiment in Germany jumped to from 106.0 to 106.7 on the EC's index, while France rose from 96 to 97.1 (where 100 is the long-term average).

10.22am GMT

Blue-chip companies with exposure to emerging markets are dominating the fallers on the FTSE 100 this morning. It's not just Diageo, although its problems in China and Nigeria have certainly hit its shares.

My colleague Nick Fletcher writes:

And the effect of a slowdown in emerging markets has been starkly illustrated by drinks giant Diageo, down 219p or 11% to £16.91 at one point before recovering to £1792.5p, 117.5p lower. The company reported sales of 1.8% in the first half, down from 2.2%, hit by weakness in China, Thailand and Nigeria. In particular a crackdown by the Chinese government on gift giving and personal spending by civil servants has hit sales of spirits.

SABMiller, another company with a strong presence in emerging markets, is down 73p at 2728.5p while Unilever has fallen 54p to £23.37, Prudential is down 27p to £12.17 and Standard Chartered is 25.5p lower at 1262p for similar reasons.

10.18am GMT

...but loans to firms still weak

Business lending in the UK, though, continues to lag the mortgage market -- underlying how consumers have been driving the recovery.

Lending to non-financial firms fell by another £1.9bn last month -- that's a surprise, as other surveys have shown that the availability of corporate credit has risen.

IHS economist Howard Archer explains that firms must be offered credit at affordable rates, otherwise the recovery could falter:

As demand for credit does pick up, it is vitally important for healthy and more balanced UK growth that all companies who are in decent shape and who do want to borrow – whether it be lift investment, explore new markets or generally support their operations – can do so, and at a non-punishing interest rate. This applies to all companies, whatever their size.

10.07am GMT

UK mortgage approvals at six-year high

Britain's housing market continued to strengthen in December, with 71,638 mortgages approved last month. That's the biggest figure since January 2008, in the early months of the financial crisis.

9.56am GMT

Turkey 'not planning capital controls'

A Turkish official has told Reuters that the country's government is not planning capital controls -- something analysts have speculated might be required if the lira keeps falling.

Here's the details:

Turkey is not considering any sort of capital controls as it battles to defend the lira, a senior government official said on Thursday, after Prime Minister Tayyip Erdogan said an "out of the ordinary" economic package could be announced soon.

"We are not working on capital controls and it is not on the table," the official told Reuters.

Under capital controls, individuals and firms are restricted from taking money out of the country, and can also be prevented from large cash withdrawals (as in Cyprus since last spring).

9.41am GMT

SA rand at new five-year low

Today's selloff pushed the South African rand down to a new five-year low against the US dollar.

Its slide accelerated after mining unions turned down a 9% pay offer from three mining companies. The proposal fell short of workers' demands for a significantly higher minimum wage (details here)

Updated at 9.42am GMT

9.28am GMT

Hungarian forint hit

The Hungarian forint is also being driven down this morning, falling another 1% to a two-year low of 312.15 against the euro.

One traders in Budapest told Reuters that the forint is feeling some of the heat directed against the lira:

"The ink has not yet even dried on the Turkish rate hike and they come against the forint".

9.20am GMT

EM currencies pummelled (again)

Emerging market currencies are also taking another pasting, in a volatile session.

The Turkish lira is currently down another 1% or so, at 2.28 to the US dollar. That means it's lost all the gains created by Tuesday night's shock interest rate hikes.

The South African Rand has also weakened around 0.8% against the US dollar, to 11.35, a day after its central bank also announced a surprise rise in borrowing costs.

Kit Juckes of Societe Generale says the twists and turns have left many traders dizzy, after Turkey's rate hike sparked only a very short-term rally in the lira:

It is easy in hindsight to point out that aggressive rate hikes at a time of moderate growth can be counter-productive, or that there were not many big speculative short positions in the lira that could be flushed out by the move...

But I didn't hear many people expressing those views when I arrived at work yesterday morning, after the rally and before the reverse. Now, many investors will be trying to keep risk at a minimum, while a few will no doubt be wondering what the next currency to come under pressure is. '

9.12am GMT

Germany's labour market has picked up again this month, as the eurozone's largest economy begins 2014 with a much larger fall in unemployment than expected.

Reuters has the details:

German unemployment fell significantly more than expected on a seasonally adjusted basis in January, Labour Office data showed on Thursday.

The number of people out of work decreased by 28,000 to 2.927m, the data showed. The mid-range forecast in a Reuters poll had been for a decrease of 5,000.

The jobless rate stood at 6.8% for January. The rate for December was revised down to 6.8% from an originally reported 6.9%.

9.03am GMT

Thought for the day, from a City fund manager with a finger in plenty of emerging market pies:

Updated at 9.03am GMT

8.57am GMT

The news that China's factory sector slowed this month (see here) has helped send shares down in emerging markets - where the Federal Reserve's decision to keep tapering has also hit sentiment.

The Indian Sensex is down 1.3% so far, South Africa's main index has lost 0.4%, and the Thai market is off 1%.

8.51am GMT

Environmental activists should be very pleased to hear that Royal Dutch Shell has abandoned plans to drill in the Alaskan Arctic this summer.

The u-turn, announced in its results this morning, comes after a US court rules that officials hadn't considered the full environmental impacts of exploring in the Chukchi and Beaufort seas.

CEO Ben van Beurden said he wasn't prepared to devote further resources to Alaska while the legal situation remained murky.

Here's the full story: Shell shelves plan to drill in Alaskan Arctic this summer

8.43am GMT

Diageo gives traders a headache

Diageo is the biggest faller in the City this morning , down over 4% after the drinks firm reported a slowdown in sales to emerging markets.

It blamed weak sales of baijiu (the strong Chinese white spirit), and also tough trading in Nigeria - where cash-strapped consumers sought out cheaper beer rather than Diageo's Guinness

Net sales were down 22% in China, and 10% in Nigeria, in the last six months.

Ivan Menezes, chief executive, said Diageo faced "a more challenging emerging market environment".

The recent turmoil in the markets, which has seen many currencies slide, won't make things easier.

More on this later

Updated at 8.43am GMT

8.37am GMT

Markets open down in Europe

In the City, the FTSE 100 has fallen 22 points in early trading to 6520, as all the main European markets open in the red.

Germany's DAX and the French CAC are broadly flat, but Spain's IBEX is down 0.4% and Italy's FTSE MIB has dropped 0.3%.

The Fed taper, and the weak Chinese factory data, aren't giving traders any reason for optimism -- especially after most Asian stock markets fell.

Ishaq Siddiqi, strategist at ETX Capital, comments:

﻿Overnight, Asian markets were rocked by the combo of Fed tapering and more importantly for the region, data which continues to point to contraction in Chinese growth – the HSBC PMI manufacturing report out of the country dipped into contraction zone to 49.5, raising fears that pace of the slowdown in China is accelerating beyond even the government’s expectations.

8.17am GMT

Spain's economy grew 0.3% in last quarter

Just in: Spain's economy has continued to claw its way out of the eurozone crisis by posting another quarter of growth.

Spanish GDP rose by 0.3% in the final three months of 2013, accelerating from the 0.1% expansion recorded in the third quarter.

The figures confirm that Spain is putting its long recession behind it, as this chart from Credit Agricole's Frederik Ducrozet shows.

On an annual basis, GDP was down by 0.1%, while the Spanish economy still shrank by 1.3% during the year.

It's not as strong as the UK's recovery (Britain's GDP grew by 0.7% in the quarter). And the Spanish jobless crisis is clearly a massive problem still. But it should fuel optimism that the eurozone periphery is making some progress out of the slump.

Updated at 9.32am GMT

8.05am GMT

HSBC: China could fine-tune policies to fight factory slowdown

The Beijing government may be concerned to hear that Chinese manufacturing output declined for the first time since last July (see opening post for the details).

Hongbin Qu, HSBC's chief economist for China, reckons Chinese officials should be ready to tweak their economic reform plans, saying:

﻿"A soft start to China's manufacturing sectors in 2014, partly due to weaker new export orders and slower domestic business activities during January. Policy makers should pay attention to downside risks and pre- emptively fine-tune policy to steady the pace of growth if needed."

The full survey is online here.

Updated at 8.06am GMT

8.02am GMT

After the taper...

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the financial markets, the world economy, business and the eurozone.

It's the morning after the taper before, as the City digests last night's message from the Federal Reserve that it has kept trimming its bond-buying stimulus programme.

Undaunted by the turmoil in emerging markets, the Fed made it pretty clear that it will keep tapering so long as the US economy appears to keep recovering. As we liveblogged last night, EM didn't even get a mention in the statement as the Fed reduced its bond-buying programme to $65bn/month.

Federal Reserve cuts additional $10bn from economic stimulus programme

The decision was unanimous -- showing America's central bank wasn't knocked off course by the slowdown in US job creation in December, or the emerging market problems.

As Michael Hewson of CMC Markets comments:

It appears that the Fed is prepared t﻿o look past the weakness in the last US jobs report of 2013 given the better than expected economic data coming from elsewhere.

The consensus also suggests that the FOMC aren’t concerned about deflationary pressures either at this point, or recent volatility in emerging markets.

And overnight, confirmation of a slowdown in China's manufacturing sector has made the markets more fretful.

The China Markit/HSBC final manufacturing PMI, which measures activity across the factory sector, fell to 49.5 this month from December's 50.5.

That's the first time in six months that the PMI has been below the 50-point mark, which separates expansion from contraction.

In a worrying sign, the survey showed output growth had eased to a "marginal pace", while jobs were cut at the fastest rate since March 2009. 

In the first deterioration in six months, Markit also reported that new export orders declined in January.

That helped wipe 1% off the Chinese stock market, while Japan's Nikkei tumbled 2.5% -- reversing all yesterday's gains.

Reaction to follow, along with other developments through the day.

Updated at 8.03am GMT
caption: ukranian crisis
title: US economy growing at 3.2% a year, fourth quarter figures show - as it happened

body:
The sound of stun grenades continue to ring out and charred vehicles are smouldering in Kiev after a night of fierce clashes between protesters and police.

The leaders of the opposition, including former heavyweight boxer Vitali Klitschko, dismissed the violence as the work of "provocateurs" and were due to hold negotiations with the government later on Monday.

The anti-government protests, which have beset Kiev for two months, escalated into fiery street battles with police on Sunday as thousands of demonstrators threw rocks and firebombs and set police vehicles on fire. Dozens of protesters were injured and 100 police sought medical attention, with 61 being admitted to hospital.

Police responded with stun grenades, teargas and, for the first time in the country's history, water cannon, but were outnumbered by the protesters. Many of the riot police held their shields over their heads to protect themselves from the projectiles thrown by demonstrators on the other side of a cordon of buses.

The violence was a sharp escalation of Ukraine's two-month political crisis, which has brought round-the-clock protest gatherings, but had been largely peaceful. President Viktor Yanukovych last week signed an array of laws severely limiting protests and banning the wearing of helmets and gas masks. Many of the demonstrators wore hardhats and masks in defiance of the new laws.

Klitschko, the leader of the Udar (Punch) opposition party, tried to calm the demonstrators down, but failed and was sprayed by a fire extinguisher in the process. "What you are doing now presets a huge danger," the reigning world heavyweight boxing champion shouted to them.

Klitschko, who said he would participate in presidential elections scheduled for spring 2015, then urged Yanukovych to announce snap presidential elections to relieve tensions. "I'm calling on Yanukovych to find strength and not repeat the fate of Ceaucescu and Gaddafi," he said, referring to the former Romanian and Libyan dictators.

He later travelled to Yanukovych's residence at Mezhyhirya outside Kiev and said the president has agreed to negotiate. Yanukovych said on his website that he had asked a working group, headed by national security council head Andriy Klyuev, to meet opposition representatives to work out a solution to the crisis.

Late last night hundreds of radical activists stormed the police cordon, attacking riot police with sticks and chains in an attempt to push their way towards the Ukrainian parliament, in front of which were parked rows of police buses.

Wearing masks and helmets to disguise their identities and equipped with sticks, chains and shields, the protesters threw stones that they had prised out from the pavement. They burned four police buses and two lorries that were blocking the road, which led to 70 policemen being wounded and 40 hospitalised, the police press service reported. With temperatures hovering at -7C, the police responded with the stun grenades and water cannon. People shouted: "Epiphany!" in response, a reference to the Orthodox Christian holiday, celebrated on Sunday, when many Ukrainians traditionally plunge into ice holes.

The police also fired rubber bullets at the protesters, medical volunteers working at the scene told the Guardian. The official opposition claimed they had nothing to do with the "provocateurs" who fought with police.

A number of western politicians and officials condemned the violence in Kiev. The US embassy said: "We urge calm and call on all sides to cease any acts provoking or resulting in violence."

The Swedish foreign minister, Carl Bildt, posted on Twitter: "I welcome the announcement in Kiev of talks to resolve the political crisis. But a solution is only possible if there is no regime repression."
caption: ukranian crisis
title: Dozens wounded in Kiev violence as anti-government protests escalate

body:
Five years after the financial crisis, America's super-rich have recovered all their losses to see their wealth reach an all-time high.

According to Forbes magazine the 400 wealthiest Americans are worth a record $2.02 trillion (£1.4tn), up from $1.7tn in 2012, a collective fortune slightly bigger than Russia's economy. In another sign of fizziness at the top of the economy, the cost to enter the billionaires' club has also gone up to levels not seen since the 2008 crash. In 2013, an aspiring plutocrat needs at least $1.3bn to make the Forbes list – the highest since just before the collapse of Lehman Brothers sent stock markets plummeting.

Bill Gates has been named as the richest American for the 20th year in a row, with a personal fortune of $72bn. The computer entrepreneur turned philanthropist recovered his position as the world's richest man in May, when he overtook mobile phone tycoon Carlos Slim, who had held the top spot for the previous four years.

Gates, the university drop-outwho founded Microsoft and has given away $28bn since 1994, saw his fortune grow by $6bn since 2012, partly helped by a rise in Microsoft's stock price since August.

In second place is Warren Buffett, the investor feted for his shrewdness, who recently bought Heinz. Buffett, with a fortune of $58.5bn, was one of the biggest gainers in 2013, which helped him retain his place on the list. The outspoken founder of software company Oracle, Larry Ellison, takes third place with a $41bn fortune.

The richest woman in the US, and the world, is Christy Walton, who inherited a retail fortune when her husband died in 2005. Walton is estimated to be worth $35.4bn, thanks to her shares in the world's largest supermarket Walmart, which has annual sales of $466bn and employs 2.2 million people worldwide – a workforce bigger than the population of Slovenia. She shares the Walmart fortune with her brother-in law Jim and sister in law Alice, who take sixth and seventh place on the list, with around $33bn each.

Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg edged into the top 20 after his personal fortune doubled to $19bnas the tech company's stock price revived over the summer, following a wobbly stock market debut in 2012.

But the social media tycoon is not the youngest on the list. That title belongs to his former dorm mate and Facebook co-founder, Dustin Moskovitz, 29, just a few days younger than Zuckerberg.

Michael Bloomberg, the mayor of New York who made a fortune with the eponymous news and data company, retains his place as America's richest politician. Bloomberg, worth $31bn and America's 10th richest individual, is due to stand down as mayor in December.

According to Forbes, one in 10 of the top 400 richest Americans are foreign-born. These include George Soros, the Hungarian-born investor, who 'broke the Bank of England' during the sterling crisis in 1992 and was wrongly pronounced dead by Reuters earlier this year. Others include Ukranian-born serial investor and London dweller Len Blavatnik ($17.8bn); Russian-born Google co-founder Sergey Brin ($24bn) and the Australian-born media tycoon Rupert Murdoch ($13.bn). Forbes reported that 34 people had slipped out of the rich list, including oilman T Boone Pickens, who lost his shirt investing in wind power at a time of falling gas prices, cutting his fortune to $950m, while AOL founder Steve Case saw his fortune fall to $1.2bn as an investment in LivingSocial, a rival to online discount website Groupon, turned sour.

title: US super-rich hit new wealth record five years after financial crisis

body:
10.13pm GMT

Full time

Peep! Peep! Peep! That's it. Spain go top of Group I, a point ahead of France. It wasn't a classic, but Spain deserved their victory. France had their chances mind, even when they went down to 10-men. Anyway, that's it from me. We hope you enjoyed our live stream and thanks for your emails. Best, Sean

10.13pm GMT

90+2 min Giroud is on for France, while Mata has replaced Iniesta.

10.13pm GMT

90+1 min France are desperately trying to win the ball back here, and when Koscielny overpresses Spain suddenly have a three-on-two. But Busquets is crowded out just when he was lining up a shot. Nearly two there ...

10.13pm GMT

90 min We'll have three minutes of added time.

10.13pm GMT

88 min France are continuing to take the game to Spain - or at least they were, but then Ribery played it straight to Arbeloa. “Pedro took his goal well, but he shouldn’t have been on the pitch!”, writes Tom Paternoster, “He should have been booked for his obvious dive in the first half & booked again for his studs-up knee-high assault on Ribéry just 3 minutes earlier. Not that I’m biased or anything.”

10.13pm GMT

87 min France have been excellent since going down to 10 men ... will they get one more chance to equalise?

10.13pm GMT

85 min France win a free-kick in a dangerous position on the corner of the penalty box after Arbeloa needlessly brings down Menez. The cross comes in, Evra gets something on it and Valdez expertly tips it wide ... although the referee blows for offside.

10.13pm GMT

84 min France are continuing to press. They couldn't, could they? "I'm drinking nothing stronger than coffee," says Matt Dony. "Caffeine counter-acts the soporific effect of Spain's midfield. Even with zero alcohol to cloud my judgement, though, I've just sent a text that was meant for my wife to my sister. What an eejit."

10.13pm GMT

83 min Nearly the equaliser from Ribery! Sissoko muscles his way through Spain's midfielder, before slipping it to Ribery on the left. He cuts in, befuddling to defenders before, just outside the box, lashing a shot which flies this much past the post.

10.13pm GMT

81 min Iniesta cuts inside and feeds Xabi, who swipes it high over the bar. Meanwhile Benzema leaves the pitch to catty boos and is replaced by Sissokko.

10.13pm GMT

80 min The French are still going for it with 10 men ... they must be ripe for the counterattack. For the merest moment it looked like Navas was in there, but Koscielny had the pace to see off the danger. Meanwhile Montenegro have just equalised against England ...

10.13pm GMT

Pogba is sent off!

78 min He's just picked up his second yellow card in a minute! There was no doubt he deserved it: he over-reached with his tackle and stamped on Xavi's boot.

10.13pm GMT

77 min Yellow card for Paul Pogba, who knees Xabi Alonso in the back of his neck. He must have been six or seven feet off the ground there.

10.13pm GMT

76 min Spain sub: Pedro off, Fabregas on. He'll be playing as a centre forward/false nine.

10.13pm GMT

75 min What a chance for Varane! Valdes stuttered and hesitated and hung about in no man's land as a France cross came over, it dropped to Varane at the back post, three or four yards out, but he stabbed it wide.

10.13pm GMT

74 min France win a corner but it Benzema's loopy header drops over the bar. Meanwhile more beer talk. "Achel Trappist is definitely not from Holland but from the Belgian town of (you guessed it) Achel," says Willem van Shaik. "The only Dutch Trappist beer is La Trappe, which I am sorry to say is slightly inferior to the Belgian trappist beers."

10.13pm GMT

71 min Another superb pass from Xavi to Navas, but Koscielny is quick to the danger. Spain look more likely to score a second than France to equalise.

10.13pm GMT

70 min France sub: Menez on, Cabaye off. "Not to be pedantic, but I believe Achel is Belgian and Koningshoeven is the Trappist brewery based in Holland," says Adam Large. "As for myself, I tend to read the MBMs while at work (and they're a life saver) so no beer for me. When I have the opportunity though, it's Founder's Breakfast Stout every time."

10.13pm GMT

69 min ... and clatters it into the wall.

10.13pm GMT

68 min: Matiudi is booked - he'll now miss France's game against Georgia in September too. Spain have a free-kick 25 yards and central. Xavi lines up to take it ...

10.13pm GMT

67 min After being a fairly conventional Spain/Barcelona v everyone else sort of game for the first hour, it's started to open up. You suspect this might favour the Spaniards more in the minutes ahead ...

10.13pm GMT

65 min ... Immediately France go up the other end and Valdes has to get down smartly to save from Benzema. Meanwhile more comments on this Spain kit ...

10.13pm GMT

64 min Navas, who has just come on for Villa (with Pedro moving into the centre) nearly set up a second there for Spain and Pedro - only for the latter to smash it over the bar ...

10.13pm GMT

62 min The Spain fans are signing: Campeones, campeones, ole, ole, ole! France are going to have to come at the Spanish now ...

10.13pm GMT

60 min Monreal, who has had an excellent game, found space down the left and was found with a featherlight pass from Xavi. He brought it in the area and skimmed a cross-shot towards Pedro. Under pressure the Spaniard got something on the ball to direct it towards goal and Lloris, falling backwards, could only palm it into the net.

10.13pm GMT

France 0-1 Spain (Pedro 59)

Spain are ahead! Pedro bundles home from close range! Cue ecstatic scenes!

10.13pm GMT

58 min A long free-kick is headed wide from 12 yards by Benzema, whose head then clatters into Busquets. The Spaniard is still rubbing his skull ...

10.13pm GMT

57 min Superb stuff from Pogba, who takes the ball off Iniesta with the ease of the school bully picking pocket money off a kid with glasses, before he jinks inside and is brought down by Xabi.

10.13pm GMT

55 min Save from Lloris, who tips Iniesta's toe-poke over the bar! Without sounding overly harsh on Iniesta, who is a wonderful player, he perhaps hit that a little too close to the French keeper there. Spain are beginning to apply the squeeze ...

10.13pm GMT

54 min Cabaye is booked, and will miss France's next qualifier away against Georgia, after a foul and a dismissive gesture at the referee.

10.13pm GMT

53 min David Villa goes down under the mildest contact from Koscielny but there's little suggestion of a foul. "I've gone for a Achel Trappist, the only Trappist Beer from Holland," writes Steve from Antwerp. "A refreshing 8%. No particular reason as I'm watching England with one eye and France with the other on mbm … I should be watching Belgium on the TV but apparently it's needed for Parade's End." Is everyone reading this enjoying a tipple?

10.13pm GMT

51 min After good hustling from Ribery, Evra wins a corner. Valdes can only paw at the cross when it eventually comes over but when the ball drops loose Benzema skies it. Cue cries of 'Giroud! Giroud!'

10.13pm GMT

49 min Valbuena goes down in the box but, apart from a sporadic boo or two, few believe it was a penalty. Meanwhile Monreal enjoys more success down the left before pulling it back to Xavi, whose first touch deserts him ...

10.13pm GMT

47 min And so the familiar pattern returns: Spain probing, France sitting and looking to counter. More reflections on Spain's kit. "It's art, Simon Frank (15th minute), and you're clearly not hip enough to understand it," suggests Matt Dony. "In two years' time, you'll be wearing a silly deep v-neck with the wrong number on your back, and Spain will be blazing another trail. Probably playing with no defenders, or something."

10.13pm GMT

46 min: Spain are out bright and early and, after France eventually trot out, the game kicks off again. Meanwhile Phil Colis writes in: "Wigan v Stoke? Accompanied by Hemlock, I would think." Harsh Phil. Harsh.

10.13pm GMT

Half-time

Peep! Peep! The referee declines to play any additional minutes so the team's enter the break level. Spain had the majority of the play but France, arguably, had at least as many decent chances. And Benzema and Ribery certainly should have done better. I'll be back in a bit.

10.13pm GMT

43 min There's a short delay as Cabaye goes down after a challenge by Monreal.

10.13pm GMT

40 min A better spell this for France but, having won a free-kick in a dangerous position, Valbuena's free-kick is poor. "I'm having a Michelada," says Bronwyn Jones. "Going out to La Esquina in NY for Mexican straight after and have to get in the mood. Sartorially, I think the Spanish have too many stripes."

10.13pm GMT

38 min What a save from Valdez! What a miss from Ribery! The Frenchman controlled a throughball exquisitely on his head and raced towards Valdez's goal; but his second touch was a little heavy and Spain's keeper was able to smother.

10.13pm GMT

35 min Another quarter-chance for Spain. Ribery back-headers it towards his own goal, Evra miscontrols and Villa has a tight chance on the angle. But his shot is screwed wide. Meanwhile Simon McMahon writes: "Serbia - Scotland (in fact, any match involving Scotland) should be accompanied by industrial quantities of Buckfast, cooking lager, whisky and .. actually, anything that would dull the pain. I'm not fussy. Just make it go away, please." Other games are available, SImon ...

10.13pm GMT

33 min See minute 21.

10.13pm GMT

32 min A Spanish player was booked in the melee following Pedro's dive there. I couldn't see who, sorry. Meanwhile Russell Brady writes: "Spain's kit is the dead spit of Melchester Rovers' togs circa 1968. This makes David Villa a latter-day Roy Race while Xavi is Blackie Gray."

10.13pm GMT

30 min: My live stream is still jumping every few seconds, making it quite hard to tell what is going on. But I could certainly see that Spain had a huge penalty appeal there: Pedro had a one-on-one with Lloris, took it past him but, in my opinion Pedro dived before he was clipped by Lloris. The referee didn't buy it either ...

10.13pm GMT

27 min Spain are still trying to play through the lines with intermittent success. "I'm drinking a robust Corbieres," says Phillipa Booth. "The name used to make me a bit nervous, but then that Findus lasagne story broke, so it seems less weird now."

10.13pm GMT

25 min Nice stuff from Pogba who holds onto the ball under pressure before finding Valbuena. Spain are having the better of this, but now and again France show their teeth ...

10.13pm GMT

23 min Typically inventive and intricate stuff from Spain ends with Busquets trundler from just outside the box being easily saved by Lloris.

10.13pm GMT

21 min Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass. Pass.

10.13pm GMT

19 min Villa gets in behind Koscielny but the assistant referee's flag is fluttering. Offside. Meanwhile Nigel in Toronto writes: "As for wine, I am finishing off a bottle of Domaine Rotier (2009) with some wonderfully ripe French triple creme. (Not imply that I've been drinking for hours; there was a glass left over from last night's dinner.)" Sure Nigel ...

10.13pm GMT

17 min Spain are trying to pick their way through one bank of four and another of five and they nearly did so there: Xavi slipped into space, 20 yards out, but his scuttler went wide of the post.

10.13pm GMT

15 min Meanwhile Simon Frank writes: "Sartorial news: that Spain kit is gruesome. I haven't seen a deeper v-neck since I started primary school in 1976. Why does Xavi play 8 and Iniesta 6 for Spain, when it's the reverse at Barça?" No idea Simon. Anyone else?

10.13pm GMT

13 min Remember Milan's strategy at home to Barcelona in the Champions League a few weeks ago? Well, France's is not entirely dissimilar. Now clearly they are on the back foot. They are going to be. This is Spain after all. But every so often Ribery and Jallet are breaking to support Benzema ... and just as I type Jallet speeds down the right to set up Benzema, who should have done better.

10.13pm GMT

11 min My live stream continues to be a bit stop-start. Apologies if you're having problems watching too. In the late 80s I remember borrowing films like Kickboxer 1 and, er, Kickboxer 2 from friends at school which may not have been entirely legitimate. The pictures tonight remind me a bit of that.

10.13pm GMT

9 min ... That said, France aren't parking the bus. And Pique has to be quick to intercept when Benzema starts thundering down the right

10.13pm GMT

6 min Spain's carousel is starting to whirl; they're beginning to tease and probe ...

10.13pm GMT

4 min What a miss from Xavi! Monreal galloped down the left to latch onto Iniesta's throughball, squared it to Xavi, eight yards out, and he smashed it over. Huge chance that for Spain. Meanwhile Peter McElduff writes regarding that whiny post on Sid Lowe's blog: "That Yalumba bush vine Grenache is excellent however. Tenner from Majestic. Don't fight the stereotype." So what wine would people drink to accompany a mbm or live stream of Montenegro v England? Bolivia v Argentina? Wigan v Stoke?

10.13pm GMT

1 min We're off. Spain wearing all-red, France in all blue. Am I the only one whose live feed is as jittery as someone who has just downed five straight cans of Red Bull?

10.13pm GMT

The national anthems ...

... the Spanish one is observed impeccably, while the Marseillaise is sung with the gusto of someone who has downed a bottle of Bordeaux and wants the world to know it.

10.13pm GMT

Our live stream ...

... is now live, for those of you who've been asking when it would be beamed out to the world (or rather Britain and Ireland). Meanwhile Rai Skrupskis emails to say: "Your intro you forgot to include 'bona nit' for all the Catalans who support Spain...eh? Oh." Ah.

10.13pm GMT

An email from Phil Podolsky. "Thing is, that Giroud goal was no suckerpunch - France were the better side in the second half and perhaps should have won it (Spain did miss out on a chance to get a two-goal cushion when Fabregas wasted a penalty late in the first period). It was the perfect demonstration why Del Bosque has repeatedly insisted on playing both Busquets and Alonso, the latter a crucial absence without whom they were outran in midfield towards the end. This pairing of holding colossi is integral to Spain's unplayablity."

That's a fair point Phil: I was referring to the time of Giroud's goal rather than the game itself. Personally thought Spain were the better team, but France did come into it more as the match went on.

10.13pm GMT

The teams are in ...

... and they are as expected: for France Valbuena keeps his place with Benzema leading the line, while for Spain Monreal starts in place of Alba, and Villa is picked as an actual No9 rather than Fabregas as a false No9.

10.13pm GMT

As you will surely have noticed, the Guardian is streaming this game live ...

... to everyone in the UK and Ireland (Apologies in advance if you're among the 60% of our readership who live elsewhere). Not that this getting something for free malarkey pleases everyone. The following comment was posted in Sid Lowe's blog earlier:

Good god the guardian is broadcasting France v Spain of course. For the more cultural football follower. Watch it tonight live from 8pm with a box of Yalumba Bush Vine Grenache. Five best new Ukranian indie bands 2013 is showing at half-time.

Do people really have nothing better to do than complain about something they don't have to watch or pay for? It's baffling, to me at any rate.

10.13pm GMT

But what of France? Like a striking French driver, most expect them to park the bus for long periods tonight. As their manager Didier Deschamps admits: "It is going to be like in the first game. I think it's useless to fight for possession with this team. But I can't prepare for the match telling the guys 'let's defend, let's defend' even if Spain put you in such a position." That said, France have their weapons. Franck Ribery is in decent nick while Mathieu Valbuena scored against Georgia and supplied two assists. One worry will be the lack of goals from Karim Benzema, who has scored just three times in his last 23 appearances in a France shirt.

10.13pm GMT

The Guardian's Sid Lowe is always required reading on all-matters Spain, and his blog on tonight's game is no different.

"This country is bipolar," Gerard Piqué told Lu Martín in El País on Tuesday morning. "People were asking if we should be more direct, if we should cross more, shoot more, and you think: have people not understood that it is playing this way that we have won everything? We have spent six or seven years winning in a way that people enjoy, having 70% of possession, generating chances: why would we change that because we have drawn a game? The world wants to play like Spain and we want to change styles? Incredible."

"Football," added Sergio Ramos, "has no memory."

As Sid points out, it is some crisis: Spain have won 22 of their last 24 qualifying games and are the reigning European and world champions ...

10.13pm GMT

Preamble

Good evening, bon soir, buenas noches ... and, as my colleague James Richardson would say, woof. Forget Montenegro v England, Bolivia v Argentina or Estonia v Andorra: this is the biggest international game of the week. Spain travel to Paris on the back of two 1-1 draws - following a late suckerpunch from France's Olivier Giroud last October and another mugging at home to Finland last Saturday - and their prospects for Rio 2014 are currently as rosy as an English garden in January.

Still, it's early days. And, crucially, Vicente Del Bosque's side, who lie two points behind France in Group I, still have matters in their own hands. Win tonight and all is good again. Lose or draw and Spain look certain to face an annoying detour via the playoffs in order to reach Rio 2014 - where, who knows, England or Portugal may lie in wait.

Shortly after 5.15pm on 10 November 2012, a jogger turned into Granville Road, Weybridge, running along the hedge-lined street of one of Britain's wealthiest enclaves. Then, 50m from his home, he staggered into the road and died.

In the days that followed, Surrey police believed they were dealing with a natural, if unusual, death. Four months on, the passing of 44-year-old Alexander Perepilichnyy still remains a mystery. Two post-mortems have proved inconclusive, but the outcome of what Surrey police promise is their "full range" of toxicology tests is imminent.

To piece together Perepilichnyy's final years is to drill down into the core of Russian criminality, according to one account.

What we know of Perepilichnyy is slight. In another age he might have been a rocket scientist. Peers called him a "genius", a Ukranian whiz-kid with an uncanny knack for numbers. His favourite waste of time was, they say, discussing the theories behind cosmogony and Kondratiev waves – the long-term cycles of capitalism. However by the time Perepilichnyy arrived to study at the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology – famous for supplying the brains behind the Soviet space race – Russia's lunar ambitions had curdled with the collapse of communism. Instead Perepilichnyy applied his talents to the world of finance and was, until 2008, a star talent at an asset management firm in Moscow.

That year, on the other side of Moscow, across Red Square and the brown Moskva river, a rival investment fund to Perepilichnyy's had become engulfed in crisis. Hermitage Capital was under the guidance of a man called Bill Browder, a naturalised Briton based in London who had built the investment firm into the largest foreign investor in Russia. But on Christmas Eve 2007, it had discovered itself to be the victim of a huge and sophisticated scam.

Browder hired Moscow-based lawyer Sergei Magnitsky, to investigate. In July 2008, Magnitsky revealed his findings detailing a web of corruption involving state tax officials and police. Magnitsky allegedly revealed how a gang of detectives, tax inspectors and convicted criminals had planned a 2007 police raid on Hermitage's Moscow office in which officers stole paperwork relating to Browder's companies. These documents were then used to secretly apply for a tax refund worth £144m.

Following the paper trail, Magnitsky found that the rebate, the largest in Russian history, had been approved at a Moscow tax office in just one day. The vast proceeds had disappeared into a shady network of accounts, according to Magnitsky. After reporting the crime to the authorities, instead of being lauded for his work, Magnitsky was arrested by police and accused of orchestrating the fraud himself. In jail, the 37-year-old was denied medical treatment, handcuffed and beaten by riot troops. He had been in prison awaiting trial for 358 days when on 16 November 2009 doctors found him dead on his cell floor in a pool of urine.

Perepilichnyy had paid close attention to Magnitsky's fate. Among his client portfolio, he soon realised, were the same senior tax officials Magnitsky had accused of perpetrating the crime against Hermitage Capital. Worse still, Perepilichnyy suspected the vast proceeds of the crime were starting to wash through the foreign corporate bank and Credit Suisse accounts which he managed.

According to associates, Perepilichnyy was "properly scared" by the death of Magnitsky. Sources say the financier feared he might be implicated in the fraud or similarly victimised if he spoke out. At the end of 2009, Perepilichnyy fled to Britain with his family and what appears to have been a vast fortune, the provenance of which still remains opaque.

One friend in Moscow, who requested anonymity, said: "Most of all he was an outstanding father. He seemed to be thinking of them 80% of his time."

Perepilichnyy believed the exclusive confines of St George's Hill in Surrey would offer sufficient protection for himself, his wife and their two young children, and began renting the six-bedroom Coach House off Granville Road for around £15,000 a month. It was a fortified mansion in an area protected by round-the-clock guards and roadblocks. As one Surrey police source explained: Perepilichnyy lived where "even the security has security".

Perepilichnyy adopted a deliberately low profile in the UK. All that changed during the summer of 2010, when he decided to follow the lead set by Magnitsky and handed over evidence and details of the Credit Suisse accounts. Hermitage in turn passed them to the Swiss police, sparking an ongoing international inquiry that has spread to six countries and resulted in the accounts of alleged Russian fraudsters being frozen.

Perepilichnyy's act put him in grave danger. By the time he went for his final jog last November, the threats against him were mounting. One corrupt official allegedly involved in the fraud against Hermitage warned "the financial wizard" to stop running scared in England because he owed money to "scores of creditors". Even the alleged killers of Litvinenko joined the long list of those with a potential motive. One of the suspects wanted for trial over the murder of the former KGB spy is among those understood to have launched legal action against Perepilichnyy, accusing him of failing to pay back debts. Perepilichnyy told business contacts in London that Moscow police agents had informed him his name was on the "hit list" of Chechen assassin groups for hire and that they had accumulated a dossier with details of his life in Surrey.

Rumours persist that he was part of the fraud against Hermitage, although his friends insist it was naivety, not greed, that brought him into danger. "He was a tragic hero," says one. "He could have been a genius professor of maths at a different time and place. He became followed, threatened and put into a corner."

Yet even at the end, Perepilichnyy had enough courage to flout the death threats and travel abroad. On the day he died, he had just returned from Paris after a three-day visit. During his sojourn in the French capital he'd booked two hotels, but it is unclear why he went to Paris or who he met there.

Investigators working for Hermitage claim the deaths of Magnitsky and Perepilichnyy are the latest in a series of suspicious deaths. They claim at least five other men who have died in strange circumstances had links to individuals they allege were involved in the fraud. The investigators paint a picture of a shadowy network of corrupt police, tax officials and criminals dubbed the Klyuev group, which is, they claim, headed by the bald, heavy-set figure of businessman Dmitry Klyuev. A spokesman for Klyuev, who is a convicted fraudster, describes the suggestion that such a group exists as a "fabrication and a lie". The spokesman pours scorn on the idea of a string of suspicious deaths and adds that Browder, whom he describes as a "corporate blackmailer", is running a highly defamatory PR campaign.

The first unusual death, according to the Hermitage investigators, came in 2005. Sergei Albaev, a former KGB officer, worked for Klyuev as a chauffeur. Documents from a Moscow court case record his wife's worry: "He became more secretive, agitated, and kept saying he had problems at work." Unknown to her, Albaev, along with his boss Klyuev, had been accused of helping orchestrate a £1.1bn fraud against Russia's biggest iron-ore producer, a criminal act that Hermitage lawyers allege was a forerunner to the attack on them.

On 3 March 2005, before Albaev could plead his innocence in court, he went on a business trip. He called his wife, saying he was in the Rostov region, 700km south of Moscow. On 8 April she received a call from a man she did not recognise. Her husband had died, said the stranger. Albaev's death certificate states he died from heart failure. Albaev was only 39. Although it was true Albaev liked a drink, smoked and weighed about 150kg, his family believes his death seemed sudden. Even now, his wife and child have no idea who he was with when he died or what he was doing.

Within weeks came another death. Alexei Alexanov had also been implicated as a key player in the attempted iron-ore fraud. Little is known about Alexanov other than, according to court transcripts, that he had known Klyuev since 1991. During a pre-trial interview, Alexanov insisted he would never sign fraudulent contracts, claiming that the implicating signatures looked nothing like his handwriting. Alexanov never had another chance to contest his innocence. Soon after, he too died in the Rostov region of heart failure. He was 46.

The next death wasn't so much strange as mistimed, according to investigators. It occurred in the wake of the fraud against Hermitage Capital. In the period after Magnitsky uncovered the crime, and before his arrest, the Russian interior ministry launched an investigation into his claims that quickly yielded a culprit. On the face of it, Oktai Gasanov from Azerbaijan seemed an unusual criminal mastermind. The 58-year-old appears to have been little more than a lowly security guard at a Moscow trading centre. But it is Gasanov's death certificate that raises the most questions. Gasanov died two months and 24 days before the actual fraud was committed. Had he been framed by police officers alleged to have been part of the syndicate that targeted Hermitage?

Then there was Valery Kurochkin – a bumbling alcoholic, according to police records, yet named by tax officials as the inheritor of Hermitage Capital. He never had time to indulge his new-found wealth: allegedly having taken a midnight train to Ukraine with five of the fraud suspects, the 48-year-old was found dead close to Boryspil international airport, near Kiev, on 30 April. His death certificate cites cirrhosis as the cause of death.

Then came Semyon Korobeinikov. Magnitsky had traced money from the Hermitage fraud to a Russian bank called USB which Klyuev had once owned but which had apparently been sold in 2006 to Korobeinikov. Before the 57-year-old could be questioned, Korobeinikov elected – according to the official report – to visit a Moscow construction site in September 2008 and climb a half-finished luxury penthouse. "Korobeinikov took himself to a big height," says the police inquiry's peculiar explanation. "His heart felt poorly, he fell down, obtaining injuries incompatible with life."

Klyuev is robust in his rejection of the claims made by Hermitage, saying that the company, and Browder, is trying to frame him. "To completely fool the public, Browder hints at various 'suspicious' deaths, cynically describing them in the context of… Dmitry Klyuev," says Klyuev's spokesman. The "Klyuev group", he says, was invented by Browder and the allegations are "unworthy and low". The spokesman accuses Browder of extensive criminal activity himself and points out that Browder is facing charges in Russia, in a case that was due to start last week.

As diplomats in Moscow and London wait nervously for the outcome of the toxicology assessments on Perepilichnyy, many believe his name may join Magnitsky's as a central source of friction between Russia and the west. In December the US Senate passed the Magnitsky Act, which imposes a visa ban and sanctions on 60 Russians implicated in the fraud and lawyer's death. The act prompted Cold War-style posturing and tit-for-tat sanctions, including President Vladimir Putin's ban on Americans adopting Russian children. Russia is pressing ahead with the posthumous prosecution of Magnitsky for tax evasion, the trial that also indicts Browder.

This prosecution has drawn widespread international condemnation and forced the European Parliament to describe it as a "violation of international and national laws". The last precedent for the posthumous trial dates back to medieval times when, in 897, the then pope held a trial of his predecessor, whose body was dug up and propped up on a chair in the papal court.

Klyuev claims the case will ensure Browder's "own crimes cannot remain hidden. [He] should honestly reveal all the accusations made against him and explain his behaviour in each specific instance."

Whether the Klyuev group exists or not, many of its alleged members appear to like London. Lawyers for Hermitage claim that analysis of flight records reveal that 61 flights between Moscow and London have carried at least one member of the so-called group since Magnitsky exposed the fraud and have identified to the Serious Fraud Office individuals who they say have laundered the fraudulent money.

If suspicions about Perepilichnyy's death were to be confirmed, the broader concern among the intelligence services is that Russian hitmen could be freely entering the UK. Hermitage employees have received at least 11 death threats, mainly text messages from phones traced to Russia. The firm's London staff report being put under surveillance by strangers, and many now follow elaborate security routines.

Former foreign minister Chris Bryant, a Labour MP, is among those perturbed that elements of the Russian mafia may be able to move freely about in London. "Undoubtedly there is a security risk in Britain at the moment," says Bryant. "There are a number of Russian operatives acting in the UK – the long arm of Russian vendettas seems to stretch over here." Browder has no doubt that he is a marked man.

Publicly, at least, no one is any wiser as to why Perepilichnyy dropped dead at the end of his jog. The ongoing police investigation is liaising with MI5, and Swiss and Russian authorities – but the latter relationship has been particularly difficult since Alexander Litvinenko's murder in 2006 in London. Perepilichnyy himself allegedly owed money to Dmitry Kovtun, one of the prime suspects wanted by British prosecutors over the poisoning. But senior Whitehall sources are keenly aware that the cause of Perepilichnyy's death has potentially seismic ramifications. If it is proven that Perepilichnyy was murdered, then no one is safe.
